clinical_study.brief_title: Increase in Temperature in Children Undergoing MRI
clinical_study.official_title: Changes in Temperature in Children Undergoing MRI

brief_summary.textblock: An increasing number of children undergo Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). In MRI, radio waves and magnetism are used to form images of the body's interior, to diagnose and monitoring diseases in children. Many children are sedated to be able to cooperate with the MRI procedure. Sedation and general anesthesia cause the child to some extent to lose the ability to regulate his or her own bodytemperature. MRI rooms are most often cold for the function of the magnet, Leading to a risk of hypothermia in young children. Conversely, the MRI scanner generates radio frequencies that are absorbed by the body and converted to heat, which especially in small children due to their large surface area can potentially result in an increase in bodytemperature. In this study we therefore want to investigate changes in bodytemperature in children who are undergoing MRI- scanning within the Neuroanesthesiology Clinic. Furthermore, we want to define possible risk factors for possible temperature changes. Our hypothesis: Children undergoing MRI scanning increase in bodytemperature.

detailed_description.textblock: Ear temperature is measured as we are primarily interested in describing temperature changes in the individual child and because this method is less invasive than the alternatives.

primary_outcome.measure: Delta temperature ∆Tp = post-temperature - pre-temperature means that the average temperature difference between pre- and post-temperature will be measured in both ear canals of the child before and after MRI scan.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Ear temperature scan within 5 minuts before and after MRI right outside the MRI suite.
primary_outcome.description: The average of the temperature measured in the two ear canals is used if the difference is less than 0.5 degrees. If the temperature difference between the two ear canals exceeds 0.5 degrees, it is assumed that the lowest temperature is an error measurement eg due to physical block of the ear canal. In that case, the highest temperature measured in one of the two ear canals is used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Childrens body surface area and temperature increase during MRI
secondary_outcome.description: Influence on body surface area calculated by weight in kilograms, height in centimeters. For calculation the Du Bois formula is used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Confounders influence on intervention and temperature outcome
secondary_outcome.description: Age ( years), height (centimeters ) BMI (kg/m^2) < 18.5 underweight, 18.5 -25 normal weight, > 25 overweight.
Influence of MRI protocol: cerebrum, neuro axis, abdominal, heart and others and MRI duration (minutes) and MRI type (Tesla 1,5 or 3,0)
Underlying diseases, infection, fever and use contrast. , use of contrast.
Use of paracetamol same day of MRI-scanning

secondary_outcome.measure: External use of cover during MRI
secondary_outcome.description: Use of blankets to prevent heat loss in babies and children undergoing MRI-scan.

other_outcome.measure: Anesthesia type and influence on body temperature
other_outcome.description: Generel anesthesia using propofol infusion or sevoflurane. Sedation or awake during MRI. ASA group 1-4

intervention.description: The temperature will be measured in both ears with an ear thermometer. Practically, we will measure the temperature twice when generel anaesthsia is established, and immidiately before and after the MRI scan.

study_pop.textblock: Children 12 weeks to 12 years of age undergoing MRI procedure with the assistance of anesthesiologists from the Neuroanesthesiology Clinic may be included. Oral and written consent from the parent or relatives of the child will be obtained in accordance with science ethical rules.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age from 12 weeks to 12 years
- Children undergoing MRI scans with the help of anesthesia staff from the Neuroanesthesiology Clinic under general anesthesia or awake
- The children are recruited via prescriptions or the anesthetist immediately before scanning and outside the MRI room. All children who meet the criteria for MRI scan can be included. Acute MRI children, children admitted to intensive care and children who came is directly from the operation if consent is obtained.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability at present. and relatives to speak and understand Danish or English. An authorized interpreter may be used for a family that does not have a Danish background and only if written and oral information material is understood otherwise the patient is excluded
- No consent to the study
- Anatomically not possible to measure ear temperature
- Temperature above 39 ° C
